subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[6.3s - 12.1s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[12.6s - 17.6s]: Today I'm so excited that we have visiting with us Brian, check, hi Brian.

[17.8s - 17.9s]: Hi.

[18.4s - 19.6s]: Welcome to the programs, you alright?

[20.8s - 28.1s]: Brian is an ecological economist and is the executive director of the Center for the

[28.1s - 32.5s]: Advancement of the Steady State Economy, also known as Cassie.

[33.7s - 38.6s]: Brian spent nearly 20 years at the United States Fish and Wildlife Service headquarters

[38.6s - 42.2s]: before resigning in 2017 to run Cassie.

[42.7s - 51.9s]: His books include Supply Shock, Shouveling Fuel for a Runaway Train, and the Endangered Species Act,

[52.3s - 55.8s]: History, Conservation Biology and Public Policy.

[56.7s - 64.6s]: Brian has a PhD from the University of Arizona and is a leading figure in ecological economics.

[65.4s - 72.8s]: I would like to also note that he was the first conservation biologist ever hired by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service

[72.8s - 84.4s]: and that Cassie has been awarded the Eco-Champion Award by public employees for environmental responsibility known as Peer

[84.4s - 95.2s]: for their work in the arena of limits to growth and ecological carrying capacity and integrity here on Earth.

[96.1s - 102.6s]: And Brian, I'm so thrilled we have the opportunity to speak together today and I think it's just hilarious.

[102.7s - 104.2s]: Here we are at a park.

[104.3s - 106.0s]: We're having to meet up in Aspen.

[106.4s - 109.3s]: We're both traveling through the High Mountains of Colorado.

[109.6s - 112.5s]: It's been raining for, I don't know, 20-25 minutes or something.

[112.5s - 118.9s]: And we are under a beautiful blue spruce which has more or less shielded all the rain from us.

[119.7s - 121.4s]: So here we are.

[121.9s - 126.3s]: And welcome, Brian, and thank you for taking the time to visit with us.

[126.5s - 126.8s]: Thank you.

[127.1s - 127.3s]: Thanks.

[128.4s - 133.2s]: So why don't you kick us off framing the conversation?

[133.2s - 144.1s]: What is all this about, what is the issue when we're talking about a steady state economy versus a perpetually growing economy?

[145.3s - 150.0s]: Well, I think it always helps to remind people what economic growth is.

[150.2s - 156.1s]: It's simply increasing production and consumption of goods and services in the aggregate.

[157.1s - 165.4s]: And so that means growing human population and or per capita production and consumption and it's measured with GDP.

[167.0s - 170.5s]: And that's an acronym that stands for growth and domestic product.

[171.3s - 178.7s]: And we sometimes call it growth domestic problem because it's beginning to cause more problems than it solves.

[178.7s - 179.1s]: Yeah.

[179.6s - 185.3s]: There are of course tremendous benefits to economic production.

[185.8s - 192.9s]: But there are at this stage in human history tremendous impacts.

[193.5s - 197.8s]: And any environmental impact, it's not just a tree hugger issue.

[198.5s - 201.6s]: The environment is the foundation of the economy.

[201.6s - 213.7s]: So there's a we say that there is a fundamental conflict fundamental because it can't be gotten out of with just technological progress.

[213.7s - 214.1s]: Yes.

[214.1s - 229.9s]: For example, a fundamental fundamental conflict between economic growth and four things four categories of things environmental protection, economic sustainability, national security and international stability.

[229.9s - 231.9s]: More or less in that order.

[232.8s - 247.0s]: Although you might say well, it's the international stability that comes before the national security because international instability is such a great threat as well to national security.

[248.1s - 248.8s]: It's so interesting.

[248.8s - 278.3s]: I have been struck working in and around the field of economics as it relates to environmental sustainability and that it has been the militaries by and large the intelligence community and the reinsurance industries who were most advanced in understanding some of these major systemic risks that we have been facing out several decades creep in a bit closer now.

[278.3s - 290.3s]: And that these issues of international stability, national security are so intimately linked with environmental protection and economic sustainability from a policy standpoint.

[291.0s - 306.0s]: It seems, Gali, some of our, I don't want to use the term knucklehead on a recording like this, but some of our friends and colleagues in Congress and inside DC could do a little better in understanding some of these connections.

[306.0s - 315.1s]: And you know, there really is, we live in a giant ecology planet earth.

[315.5s - 320.0s]: It's a contained and limited system, a beautiful one.

[320.6s - 326.2s]: And we share it with all our other human brothers and sisters all around the planet.

[326.8s - 341.6s]: So I just am so struck that getting into a conversation around economics and the assumptions that we're working within our culture when it comes to economics, there's a lot there that needs to be looked at and examined.

[341.6s - 355.8s]: And, you know, for sure. And the part about limits to growth, I mean that shouldn't be that it's not rocket science that you can have a perpetually growing economy.

[356.0s - 370.8s]: I mean, what are we going to have a trillion quadrillion gazillion GDP when we think in these ridiculous terms, that's when we usually start to get some buy-in, even from conventional economists.

[370.8s - 380.5s]: Well, yeah, sure, there probably are limits to growth, but there's so far out there that why, you know, why should we even bother thinking about that now.

[381.0s - 388.5s]: But that's a whole different discussion, all of a sudden, than whether or not there is a limit-deep, economic growth.

[388.5s - 395.5s]: Yeah, once we all agree that, yeah, of course, you can't not, you can't have a perpetually growing economy.

[396.0s - 402.6s]: Then the question is, well, where should we stop that growth of the economy?

[402.8s - 406.8s]: When, when is it starting to cause more problems than it solves?

[406.8s - 420.6s]: Yeah. And a lot of us, you know, that love the wide open spaces and big trees and wildlife and solitude, you know, we think it's already post-optimal.

[421.0s - 427.4s]: The economy is already too big for optimum conditions on the earth.

[428.2s - 431.9s]: And I think there's a lot of people are starting to agree with this.

[431.9s - 443.1s]: Yeah. It's not just the natural world. Now, it's creeping into our economies. It's harder and harder to maintain this level of economic activity in the US and on the globe.

[444.8s - 456.5s]: And it is very, yeah, tightly connected with international stability and national security, not only from the pressures caused by international instability,

[456.5s - 466.1s]: but the need for economic sustainability to maintain, for example, a military, much less a healthy society.

[467.0s - 474.3s]: So I'm struck that we'll be on this episode talking a bit about different aspects of the economics.

[474.8s - 479.7s]: And I forget who said it, but somebody called economics the dismal science.

[479.7s - 500.0s]: Right. I know for sure it's not every one of our favorite subjects, but nonetheless, I think it really is important for us as citizens, as voters, as participants in this momentous time in the human story that we have some working understanding of some of these economic principles.

[500.0s - 513.3s]: And with that in mind, I'm hoping, you know, we're talking about some debates that have been going on for decades, even a couple centuries, going back to the late 1800s.

[513.9s - 524.5s]: The Enlightenment period, we had the Scottish Enlightenment, most famous among them being probably Adam Smith who wrote Wealth of Nations, published 1776.

[525.2s - 533.9s]: And across the water there, we had the French physiocrats very focused on the natural foundation of economic production and activity.

[534.6s - 542.7s]: And I was hoping you could walk through when we're talking about primary, secondary, tertiary, all these steps and kind of what's going on in that broader economic picture.

[543.3s - 549.8s]: Just walk us through how we understand that to be working. It would be helpful, I'm sure, for many in our audience.

[549.8s - 556.3s]: Yeah, well, in ecological economics, we call that the trophic structure of the economy.

[559.1s - 569.9s]: So, if we start with the economy of nature, which both Francois Canne and the physiocrats and Adam Smith had a pretty good grasp of, you know, they were renaissance men.

[569.9s - 580.6s]: They understood the bigger picture of the world. They knew a lot about agricultural production and how the natural world worked and how that linked into economic activity.

[581.4s - 594.2s]: So, in the economy of nature, you know, you have the, at the base of that, the producers, the plants, you know, called producers because they produce their own food via the process of photosynthesis.

[594.2s - 604.1s]: And then what eats the plants, those are primary consumers. And then what consumes the primary consumers are secondary consumers, like predators.

[605.0s - 610.4s]: So, that's the very basics of the structure of the economy of nature.

[610.9s - 618.0s]: And, you know, there are service providers, two like decomposers and scavengers and pollinators.

[618.0s - 632.1s]: So, humans come along, evolve and were created there now and they're part of this economy of nature and they're at the pinnacle of this trophic structure.

[632.3s - 636.2s]: For one thing, they can eat anything else out there that's edible.

[637.6s - 646.8s]: And they also have to follow the same basic rules of the game. They have a trophic structure in their economy.

[646.8s - 658.2s]: They're like a subset of that broader economy of nature. And if you take this subset out and analyze it, it has its trophic structure.

[658.4s - 663.9s]: So, it starts with the agricultural and extractive sectors, those are the producers.

[664.5s - 672.4s]: That would be like forestry, fishing, mining, these kinds of taking from earth and earth's productivity directly.

[672.4s - 680.4s]: Exactly, directly. And then built upon that, you have the manufacturing sectors.

[681.1s - 692.7s]: And these are the basic trophic levels. Heavy manufacturing, iron ore refining, all the way up to the lightest sectors like computer chip manufacturing.

[693.0s - 696.3s]: Yeah, folks making cell phones and all that kind of business.

[696.3s - 702.2s]: And mix all throughout that our service sectors just like in the economy of nature.

[705.3s - 716.1s]: And so, it's actually a good way to view the fundamental conflict between economic growth and environmental protection.

[716.1s - 730.4s]: Because as that part of the economy of nature continues to expand, it's like a trophic compression of all the other species below in that the broader economy of nature.

[731.1s - 743.1s]: So, when you look at the list of species that are endangered, this burgeoning list of threatened and endangered species, and you look at the causes of their endangerment,

[743.3s - 746.2s]: it's like a who's who of the American economy.

[746.7s - 760.0s]: Right, just this and that sector one after another, that is what's pushed, that's what is liquidating the habitats that species require to make a living in.

[760.6s - 768.7s]: And same thing with animal and plant species being squeezed out by that growth of the human economy.

[768.7s - 785.8s]: Yeah, well we're certainly living in precarious times and I just heard recently that at the time approximately of I want to say, President Franklin Roosevelt,

[786.1s - 790.8s]: was it, or maybe it's Teddy Roosevelt, there were about two billion people on the planet.

[790.8s - 798.1s]: And now just over 100 years or about 100 years later, we have about seven and a half billion people on the planet.

[798.9s - 807.6s]: And you know, many of my friends working in the realm of social justice as it relates especially to the environmental issues that we're concerned with,

[808.3s - 820.7s]: point out that some of the population discussion or debate is very loaded with social justice issues and really ethical issues and issues that require us to look at the environment.

[820.7s - 826.1s]: We're going to look at our human decency and matters of dignity and matters of the heart, if you will.

[826.5s - 838.3s]: But that all aside for just a moment, just looking purely at the numbers of growing from something like two billion to almost four times as much within just a few generations,

[838.8s - 848.2s]: that's obviously a pattern you don't want to see perpetuating or continuing for too many more generations in this situation.

[848.2s - 854.5s]: It should be obvious, shouldn't it? India alone has a billion people.

[855.6s - 868.3s]: And people that are at the, that do not consume as wastefully in a per capita basis as they do in the US, for example.

[868.3s - 879.7s]: And nevertheless, you can already see the signs of resource shortage that much of Tamil Nadu in southern India is without water.

[880.5s - 889.5s]: It's a perilous existence in cities like Chennai, huge cities in southern India and there's no end in sight.

[890.3s - 895.7s]: It's not only climate change, it's the use of the water resources there.

[896.5s - 917.7s]: And water is the lifeblood of the economy. I mean some people might say it's oil, okay, you know, lifeblood, energy, the calories required, one's oil, one's water, they're both required for this level of economic activity, you know, an 82 trillion dollar global economy right now.

[919.7s - 929.5s]: And so the economy once again going back to the earliest minutes of this, it's population times per capita production and consumption.

[929.8s - 929.9s]: Yeah.

[930.2s - 935.6s]: Either one's too high, gets to be too much for the planet and the future economy.

[936.2s - 941.9s]: Yeah, I just, I have to point out or I know a few of my friends will give me a hard time afterward.

[941.9s - 955.8s]: With respect to the water and the oil piece, so many folks now are working on solutions to transition from oil. Clearly there are a whole number of reasons why that's worthwhile and thankfully underway.

[956.5s - 964.2s]: Water on the other hand, there's no substitute for water. Water is life. Our bodies obviously are composed of it, 70% are better.

[964.8s - 988.8s]: Same as the surface of the planet itself, interestingly. And so clearly when we're now confronted with situations around the planet where more and more of us do not have access to water, that ought to be on its face enough for us to be thinking about these economic issues hands down.

[988.8s - 1012.0s]: Absolutely. And it's, I think that although it seems like economic growth is so insconced as the primary policy goal around the world, it's, you can see the cracks in that firmament, if you will, in a lot of countries now and a lot of parts of the world.

[1012.9s - 1024.3s]: But, Bhutan, moving to the pursuit of gross national happiness, because they see all the unhappiness around the world associated with pulling out all the stops for GDP growth.

[1025.5s - 1038.9s]: Even before that, the Thailand's idea of the sufficiency economy rather than more and more every year, they're precedence for this.

[1038.9s - 1061.2s]: And it's a logical way to go. It's the ethical way to go. And it's the diplomatic way to go. I mean, when we call for a steady state economy in the US, obviously that's not sufficient for global sustainability.

[1061.2s - 1088.2s]: So we have a vision for steady statesmanship we like to call it, in international diplomacy. We have to figure out where are the biggest problems in terms of the per capita consumption, where is the most wasteful consumption, and where are populations burgeoning so rapidly that the rest of the world can absorb those rates of immigration?

[1088.2s - 1101.1s]: Both of these things have to really be wrestled with seriously in international diplomacy. Growth is not the answer. Growth is just compounding both of those two problems.

[1101.1s - 1116.1s]: Yes, absolutely. Hey, you know, I love the discussion around the gross national happiness work that's being done in Bhutan. And I imagine some of our audience may not be familiar. Is that something you can tell us a little more about?

[1116.1s - 1136.5s]: A little more. Yeah. So there was Bhutan was a kingdom. Yeah. As little as seven years ago, maybe, and the king of Bhutan did look around and had become familiar with some of the principles of ecological economics.

[1136.5s - 1156.1s]: I think he was familiarized partially through the Convention on Biological Diversity that heads of state attended. And, you know, and there's sort of a bit of a common sense out there now around the world that there's serious environmental problems.

[1156.1s - 1172.8s]: And that is such a spectacularly beautiful country. And the people from Bhutan are proud of that. You know, meet the people from there. They are happy. How could it you be in such a spectacular place?

[1172.8s - 1196.9s]: And so they want to keep it that way. They look out at what they have and they don't want that to change dramatically. They don't want bulldozers coming in and skyscrapers messing that up. So he said to the people, you know, GDP is not what we're after. We're after gross national happiness.

[1196.9s - 1216.5s]: And concurrently with that, as you know, he moved that government into a ministerial government. So that's kind of a very nice sequence of events, both what we might call steady statesmanship, corresponding with a more democratic form of government.

[1216.5s - 1245.2s]: Absolutely beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. I just want to make a quick note for it slips my mind. And that reminds me of something we were discussing earlier, which is often the activities we can engage in on a day-to-day basis that are most conducive to our health, our well-being, our high quality of life.

[1245.2s - 1263.3s]: Our activities where we're not buying and consuming here, here we are under a blue spruce. It's been raining a while. We've been standing here a while. It's been absolutely delightful. We're getting so much benefit in the fresh air and I wish you was throwing off a little more heat.

[1264.7s - 1285.4s]: But you know, here we are and we're not spending money to be right here. Yeah, good point. Because money originates, you know, with that agricultural and extractive activity at the base that goes back to the trophic structure of the economy.

[1285.4s - 1306.0s]: When it comes to monetary matters, we call that, well, we call it the trophic theory of money because money does originate via the agricultural surplus, especially that frees the hands for the division of labor into all these different activities, economic activities.

[1306.7s - 1334.8s]: But you know, a lot of the pleasures of life, like, you know, the folks that just came around walking the dog with the little grandkids and stuff that didn't cost anything. And it's not nobody's paying for that or extracting resources in any, you know, they obviously had to make a living, to feed the family. There's the base level. Nobody's saying don't have any economic activity to matter how much.

[1334.8s - 1353.2s]: Yeah, the appropriate levels, appropriate levels. Yeah. Well, I'm really struck about the fact that you're doing a whole lot of work at the policy level working with lawmakers, et cetera. And I want to make sure we get to that in a couple of minutes.

[1353.2s - 1369.0s]: But of course, with the Y on Earth community, we also, in addition to our civic work and conversations with policymakers, et cetera, we are also very focused on what can we do in our day-to-day lives, folks from all sorts of backgrounds.

[1369.6s - 1380.1s]: And one of the things you mentioned earlier to me before we started the recording that really, really stuck is your emphasis on spending less, simply spending less.

[1380.1s - 1398.5s]: Certainly. When we were just talking about how more money, the supply of money and the flow of money, money supplies like the M0, the M1, the liquid types of money supplies, and flows of money like GDP.

[1398.5s - 1412.0s]: These are outstanding indicators of environmental impact. Right. At this point in history, GDP is probably a better indicator of environmental impact than it is of any kind of well-being.

[1412.8s - 1413.3s]: Absolutely.

[1413.3s - 1428.5s]: So spending less that entails a little less of that economic activity, you know, why purchase something that's already provided by nature.

[1428.7s - 1438.7s]: We didn't have to go out and buy a tent that would have required more surplus at that economic base. There's already a tree here we can stand under.

[1440.4s - 1447.2s]: There's examples just one after another in the course of a day of a human life.

[1448.0s - 1448.7s]: Yeah.

[1450.2s - 1461.8s]: This one will seem maybe kind of corny, but when you wash your hands, you don't necessarily have to pull out a paper towel or run some electric drier.

[1461.8s - 1471.3s]: You know, think about the 300-some million people in the country that are doing that several times a day, that stuff really adds up.

[1471.7s - 1474.4s]: It really does. It absolutely does.

[1474.6s - 1481.0s]: Yeah. Paper cups, straws, all of that. But, well, you're getting me rolling now.

[1481.0s - 1481.6s]: Yeah, sorry.

[1481.6s - 1486.9s]: I have to say it, I can't stand those hummers.

[1487.9s - 1495.2s]: And thank goodness the hummer demand seems to have abated. But for a while, hummers were all the rage.

[1496.1s - 1509.8s]: And during the Gulf wars, besides what a horrible symbolism that was and what an awful example of conspicuous consumption that is not only unsustainable,

[1509.8s - 1523.5s]: but you know, way it alone was a threat to national security because it makes Americans or whichever country's behaving like that makes us look bad.

[1524.0s - 1524.4s]: It really does.

[1524.4s - 1525.6s]: It really does look like greedy pigs.

[1525.9s - 1526.4s]: Truly.

[1527.0s - 1533.9s]: And then we want to shut down the borders from people that have orders of magnitude less.

[1534.7s - 1537.9s]: Those two things combined look really bad.

[1537.9s - 1541.2s]: Right. We're not looking like good citizens in the neighborhood.

[1541.9s - 1542.3s]: Exactly.

[1542.6s - 1543.0s]: In this way.

[1543.5s - 1543.8s]: Yeah.

[1544.4s - 1558.0s]: Yep. You know, it reminds me too, you know, when we're taking a walk, say, or just having a nice chat in the park with somebody for a couple hours, we're not contributing to GDP at that point.

[1558.5s - 1563.5s]: However, if in a scenario, say I was walking down the street, I got hit by a car.

[1563.8s - 1565.2s]: An ambulance had to come get me.

[1565.6s - 1566.8s]: Take me to a hospital.

[1567.2s - 1571.4s]: Meanwhile, I got news. Perhaps I was about to get a divorce or something.

[1571.5s - 1572.4s]: I'm not actually married.

[1573.2s - 1576.6s]: But you know, and had to get some lawyers in the mix at this, that and the other.

[1577.0s - 1580.2s]: You know, I could have all of these really terrible things happening to me.

[1580.3s - 1580.8s]: But guess what?

[1580.9s - 1582.8s]: Those are all positive contributors to GDP.

[1583.4s - 1586.4s]: Well, good thing you didn't get hit by a hummer.

[1586.4s - 1587.2s]: Oh, yeah.

[1587.5s - 1590.2s]: Even the worst of all worlds.

[1590.8s - 1604.6s]: But I think it just illustrates that for a lot of us, maybe who we haven't thought about this quite as much, GDP is not at all an indicator as to quality of life as to how well things are going.

[1605.0s - 1605.1s]: Right.

[1606.1s - 1622.8s]: To be fair to conventional economics and conventional economists, in countries with truly widespread poverty, then GDP per capita is a useful metric.

[1623.6s - 1625.6s]: But you can't get carried away.

[1625.8s - 1629.5s]: It's not the only metric because of the examples like the ones you just mentioned.

[1630.5s - 1642.1s]: But certainly in a country where the vast majority is reasonably well fed and sheltered and far beyond that, frankly.

[1643.5s - 1657.4s]: Then the GDP per capita is causing just as many problems as it's solving and human health and social life and political life.

[1658.4s - 1678.7s]: And so that's why, you know, way back in the 1860s, John Stuart Mill, you're probably very familiar with, was calling already for what he called a stationary state, which had nothing to do with a stagnating economy or society.

[1678.7s - 1696.3s]: In a steady state economy, there's plenty of room for technological replacement for consumer preferences to shift for all kinds of economic dynamism, dynamic changes in the economy.

[1696.4s - 1703.5s]: It's just the size of that thing that is what matters in terms of sustainability. That's what matters the most.

[1703.5s - 1733.5s]: And so John Stuart Mill recognized that way back in the 1860s in England and said, you know, why don't we focus more on quality of life outside of this economic activity, you know, political life and civil life and civil rights and reforms and, you know, improving child education.

[1734.5s - 1749.0s]: And all the other things that oftentimes are actually competed for by, you know, regular economic activities that go into that are included in GDP calculations.

[1749.5s - 1750.9s]: Yeah, yeah, absolutely.

[1751.8s - 1752.4s]: Absolutely.

[1753.5s - 1759.4s]: I would love if we could share a little bit about the Cassie position on economic growth.

[1759.4s - 1769.8s]: And I want to mention that folks, if you'd like to learn more and you can actually, there's a great really quick video at steadystate.org.

[1770.8s - 1781.2s]: And on there, you can also check out and if you would like to, you can become a signer of the Cassie position on economic growth.

[1781.5s - 1792.6s]: By the way, there are already 14,000 signatures, signatories and 215 organizations as well have endorsed this.

[1792.6s - 1800.0s]: So you can see here, it's kind of a full page, which is a summary of something that's fairly complex.

[1800.4s - 1804.1s]: But I thought it might be nice to read a few of the highlights if that sounds good, Brian.

[1804.3s - 1804.8s]: Yeah, nice.

[1804.8s - 1807.3s]: And you want me to go forward or you want to do it.

[1807.9s - 1808.2s]: Okay.

[1808.5s - 1821.6s]: So it says, whereas economic growth as defined in standard economics textbooks is an increase in the production and consumption of goods and services based upon established principles of physics and ecology,

[1821.8s - 1825.2s]: there is a limit to economic growth.

[1825.7s - 1833.8s]: Therefore, we take the position that there is a fundamental conflict between economic growth and environmental protection.

[1835.0s - 1841.2s]: For example, biodiversity conservation, clean air and water, atmospheric stability.

[1842.5s - 1859.9s]: And a steady state economy, that is an economy with a relatively stable, mildly fluctuating production of population and per capita consumption, is a viable alternative to a growing economy and has become a more appropriate goal in large, wealthy economies.

[1860.7s - 1874.6s]: And for many nations with widespread poverty, increasing per capita consumption or alternatively more equitable distributions of wealth remains an appropriate goal.

[1875.5s - 1889.8s]: So what I love about this framework is that it is speaking to and encompassing a lot of complexity, but specifically is calling out that there are different appropriate courses for the wealthy, more developed nations versus the poor.

[1889.8s - 1895.3s]: And the poorest economies around the world, and I really appreciate that it recognizes that subtlety.

[1895.8s - 1904.4s]: Yeah. We had to or just it makes ethical sense and it makes political sense, frankly.

[1904.9s - 1905.0s]: Yeah.

[1905.0s - 1911.3s]: Yeah, I guess you showed that to them, but the Cassie position has 16 sentences.

[1911.7s - 1920.1s]: And so Aaron just read like five that kind of summarized this thing that's already a summary of, yeah, see a complex issue.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.
Today I'm so excited that we have visiting with us Brian, check, hi Brian.
Hi.
Welcome to the programs, you alright?
Brian is an ecological economist and is the executive director of the Center for the
Advancement of the Steady State Economy, also known as Cassie.
Brian spent nearly 20 years at the United States Fish and Wildlife Service headquarters
before resigning in 2017 to run Cassie.
His books include Supply Shock, Shouveling Fuel for a Runaway Train, and the Endangered Species Act,
History, Conservation Biology and Public Policy.
Brian has a PhD from the University of Arizona and is a leading figure in ecological economics.
I would like to also note that he was the first conservation biologist ever hired by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service
and that Cassie has been awarded the Eco-Champion Award by public employees for environmental responsibility known as Peer
for their work in the arena of limits to growth and ecological carrying capacity and integrity here on Earth.
And Brian, I'm so thrilled we have the opportunity to speak together today and I think it's just hilarious.
Here we are at a park.
We're having to meet up in Aspen.
We're both traveling through the High Mountains of Colorado.
It's been raining for, I don't know, 20-25 minutes or something.
And we are under a beautiful blue spruce which has more or less shielded all the rain from us.
So here we are.
And welcome, Brian, and thank you for taking the time to visit with us.
Thank you.
Thanks.
So why don't you kick us off framing the conversation?
What is all this about, what is the issue when we're talking about a steady state economy versus a perpetually growing economy?
Well, I think it always helps to remind people what economic growth is.
It's simply increasing production and consumption of goods and services in the aggregate.
And so that means growing human population and or per capita production and consumption and it's measured with GDP.
And that's an acronym that stands for growth and domestic product.
And we sometimes call it growth domestic problem because it's beginning to cause more problems than it solves.
Yeah.
There are of course tremendous benefits to economic production.
But there are at this stage in human history tremendous impacts.
And any environmental impact, it's not just a tree hugger issue.
The environment is the foundation of the economy.
So there's a we say that there is a fundamental conflict fundamental because it can't be gotten out of with just technological progress.
Yes.

For example, a fundamental fundamental conflict between economic growth and four things four categories of things environmental protection, economic sustainability, national security and international stability.
More or less in that order.
Although you might say well, it's the international stability that comes before the national security because international instability is such a great threat as well to national security.
It's so interesting.

I have been struck working in and around the field of economics as it relates to environmental sustainability and that it has been the militaries by and large the intelligence community and the reinsurance industries who were most advanced in understanding some of these major systemic risks that we have been facing out several decades creep in a bit closer now.
And that these issues of international stability, national security are so intimately linked with environmental protection and economic sustainability from a policy standpoint.

It seems, Gali, some of our, I don't want to use the term knucklehead on a recording like this, but some of our friends and colleagues in Congress and inside DC could do a little better in understanding some of these connections.
And you know, there really is, we live in a giant ecology planet earth.
It's a contained and limited system, a beautiful one.
And we share it with all our other human brothers and sisters all around the planet.

So I just am so struck that getting into a conversation around economics and the assumptions that we're working within our culture when it comes to economics, there's a lot there that needs to be looked at and examined.
And, you know, for sure. And the part about limits to growth, I mean that shouldn't be that it's not rocket science that you can have a perpetually growing economy.
I mean, what are we going to have a trillion quadrillion gazillion GDP when we think in these ridiculous terms, that's when we usually start to get some buy-in, even from conventional economists.
Well, yeah, sure, there probably are limits to growth, but there's so far out there that why, you know, why should we even bother thinking about that now.
But that's a whole different discussion, all of a sudden, than whether or not there is a limit-deep, economic growth.
Yeah, once we all agree that, yeah, of course, you can't not, you can't have a perpetually growing economy.
Then the question is, well, where should we stop that growth of the economy?
When, when is it starting to cause more problems than it solves?
Yeah. And a lot of us, you know, that love the wide open spaces and big trees and wildlife and solitude, you know, we think it's already post-optimal.
The economy is already too big for optimum conditions on the earth.
And I think there's a lot of people are starting to agree with this.
Yeah. It's not just the natural world. Now, it's creeping into our economies. It's harder and harder to maintain this level of economic activity in the US and on the globe.
And it is very, yeah, tightly connected with international stability and national security, not only from the pressures caused by international instability,
but the need for economic sustainability to maintain, for example, a military, much less a healthy society.
So I'm struck that we'll be on this episode talking a bit about different aspects of the economics.
And I forget who said it, but somebody called economics the dismal science.

Right. I know for sure it's not every one of our favorite subjects, but nonetheless, I think it really is important for us as citizens, as voters, as participants in this momentous time in the human story that we have some working understanding of some of these economic principles.
And with that in mind, I'm hoping, you know, we're talking about some debates that have been going on for decades, even a couple centuries, going back to the late 1800s.
The Enlightenment period, we had the Scottish Enlightenment, most famous among them being probably Adam Smith who wrote Wealth of Nations, published 1776.
And across the water there, we had the French physiocrats very focused on the natural foundation of economic production and activity.
And I was hoping you could walk through when we're talking about primary, secondary, tertiary, all these steps and kind of what's going on in that broader economic picture.
Just walk us through how we understand that to be working. It would be helpful, I'm sure, for many in our audience.
Yeah, well, in ecological economics, we call that the trophic structure of the economy.
So, if we start with the economy of nature, which both Francois Canne and the physiocrats and Adam Smith had a pretty good grasp of, you know, they were renaissance men.
They understood the bigger picture of the world. They knew a lot about agricultural production and how the natural world worked and how that linked into economic activity.
So, in the economy of nature, you know, you have the, at the base of that, the producers, the plants, you know, called producers because they produce their own food via the process of photosynthesis.
And then what eats the plants, those are primary consumers. And then what consumes the primary consumers are secondary consumers, like predators.
So, that's the very basics of the structure of the economy of nature.
And, you know, there are service providers, two like decomposers and scavengers and pollinators.
So, humans come along, evolve and were created there now and they're part of this economy of nature and they're at the pinnacle of this trophic structure.
For one thing, they can eat anything else out there that's edible.
And they also have to follow the same basic rules of the game. They have a trophic structure in their economy.
They're like a subset of that broader economy of nature. And if you take this subset out and analyze it, it has its trophic structure.
So, it starts with the agricultural and extractive sectors, those are the producers.
That would be like forestry, fishing, mining, these kinds of taking from earth and earth's productivity directly.
Exactly, directly. And then built upon that, you have the manufacturing sectors.
And these are the basic trophic levels. Heavy manufacturing, iron ore refining, all the way up to the lightest sectors like computer chip manufacturing.
Yeah, folks making cell phones and all that kind of business.
And mix all throughout that our service sectors just like in the economy of nature.
And so, it's actually a good way to view the fundamental conflict between economic growth and environmental protection.
Because as that part of the economy of nature continues to expand, it's like a trophic compression of all the other species below in that the broader economy of nature.
So, when you look at the list of species that are endangered, this burgeoning list of threatened and endangered species, and you look at the causes of their endangerment,
it's like a who's who of the American economy.
Right, just this and that sector one after another, that is what's pushed, that's what is liquidating the habitats that species require to make a living in.
And same thing with animal and plant species being squeezed out by that growth of the human economy.
Yeah, well we're certainly living in precarious times and I just heard recently that at the time approximately of I want to say, President Franklin Roosevelt,
was it, or maybe it's Teddy Roosevelt, there were about two billion people on the planet.
And now just over 100 years or about 100 years later, we have about seven and a half billion people on the planet.
And you know, many of my friends working in the realm of social justice as it relates especially to the environmental issues that we're concerned with,
point out that some of the population discussion or debate is very loaded with social justice issues and really ethical issues and issues that require us to look at the environment.
We're going to look at our human decency and matters of dignity and matters of the heart, if you will.
But that all aside for just a moment, just looking purely at the numbers of growing from something like two billion to almost four times as much within just a few generations,
that's obviously a pattern you don't want to see perpetuating or continuing for too many more generations in this situation.
It should be obvious, shouldn't it? India alone has a billion people.
And people that are at the, that do not consume as wastefully in a per capita basis as they do in the US, for example.
And nevertheless, you can already see the signs of resource shortage that much of Tamil Nadu in southern India is without water.
It's a perilous existence in cities like Chennai, huge cities in southern India and there's no end in sight.
It's not only climate change, it's the use of the water resources there.

And water is the lifeblood of the economy. I mean some people might say it's oil, okay, you know, lifeblood, energy, the calories required, one's oil, one's water, they're both required for this level of economic activity, you know, an 82 trillion dollar global economy right now.
And so the economy once again going back to the earliest minutes of this, it's population times per capita production and consumption.
Yeah.
Either one's too high, gets to be too much for the planet and the future economy.
Yeah, I just, I have to point out or I know a few of my friends will give me a hard time afterward.

With respect to the water and the oil piece, so many folks now are working on solutions to transition from oil. Clearly there are a whole number of reasons why that's worthwhile and thankfully underway.
Water on the other hand, there's no substitute for water. Water is life. Our bodies obviously are composed of it, 70% are better.

Same as the surface of the planet itself, interestingly. And so clearly when we're now confronted with situations around the planet where more and more of us do not have access to water, that ought to be on its face enough for us to be thinking about these economic issues hands down.

Absolutely. And it's, I think that although it seems like economic growth is so insconced as the primary policy goal around the world, it's, you can see the cracks in that firmament, if you will, in a lot of countries now and a lot of parts of the world.
But, Bhutan, moving to the pursuit of gross national happiness, because they see all the unhappiness around the world associated with pulling out all the stops for GDP growth.
Even before that, the Thailand's idea of the sufficiency economy rather than more and more every year, they're precedence for this.

And it's a logical way to go. It's the ethical way to go. And it's the diplomatic way to go. I mean, when we call for a steady state economy in the US, obviously that's not sufficient for global sustainability.

So we have a vision for steady statesmanship we like to call it, in international diplomacy. We have to figure out where are the biggest problems in terms of the per capita consumption, where is the most wasteful consumption, and where are populations burgeoning so rapidly that the rest of the world can absorb those rates of immigration?
Both of these things have to really be wrestled with seriously in international diplomacy. Growth is not the answer. Growth is just compounding both of those two problems.

Yes, absolutely. Hey, you know, I love the discussion around the gross national happiness work that's being done in Bhutan. And I imagine some of our audience may not be familiar. Is that something you can tell us a little more about?

A little more. Yeah. So there was Bhutan was a kingdom. Yeah. As little as seven years ago, maybe, and the king of Bhutan did look around and had become familiar with some of the principles of ecological economics.

I think he was familiarized partially through the Convention on Biological Diversity that heads of state attended. And, you know, and there's sort of a bit of a common sense out there now around the world that there's serious environmental problems.

And that is such a spectacularly beautiful country. And the people from Bhutan are proud of that. You know, meet the people from there. They are happy. How could it you be in such a spectacular place?

And so they want to keep it that way. They look out at what they have and they don't want that to change dramatically. They don't want bulldozers coming in and skyscrapers messing that up. So he said to the people, you know, GDP is not what we're after. We're after gross national happiness.

And concurrently with that, as you know, he moved that government into a ministerial government. So that's kind of a very nice sequence of events, both what we might call steady statesmanship, corresponding with a more democratic form of government.

Absolutely beautiful. Absolutely beautiful. I just want to make a quick note for it slips my mind. And that reminds me of something we were discussing earlier, which is often the activities we can engage in on a day-to-day basis that are most conducive to our health, our well-being, our high quality of life.

Our activities where we're not buying and consuming here, here we are under a blue spruce. It's been raining a while. We've been standing here a while. It's been absolutely delightful. We're getting so much benefit in the fresh air and I wish you was throwing off a little more heat.

But you know, here we are and we're not spending money to be right here. Yeah, good point. Because money originates, you know, with that agricultural and extractive activity at the base that goes back to the trophic structure of the economy.

When it comes to monetary matters, we call that, well, we call it the trophic theory of money because money does originate via the agricultural surplus, especially that frees the hands for the division of labor into all these different activities, economic activities.

But you know, a lot of the pleasures of life, like, you know, the folks that just came around walking the dog with the little grandkids and stuff that didn't cost anything. And it's not nobody's paying for that or extracting resources in any, you know, they obviously had to make a living, to feed the family. There's the base level. Nobody's saying don't have any economic activity to matter how much.

Yeah, the appropriate levels, appropriate levels. Yeah. Well, I'm really struck about the fact that you're doing a whole lot of work at the policy level working with lawmakers, et cetera. And I want to make sure we get to that in a couple of minutes.
